subject: Law
title: Gideon v. Wainwright: Right to a Lawyer
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Gideon v. Wainwright: Right to a Lawyer.

hook.text: Clarence Gideon was too poor to hire a lawyer. He defended himself, lost, and went to prison. Then he wrote a letter.

buildup.text: From prison, Gideon petitioned the Supreme Court in pencil on lined paper. The Court agreed to hear his case.

discovery.text: In 1963, the Court unanimously ruled that states must provide lawyers to defendants who can't afford one.

twist.text: Gideon got a retrial with a real lawyerâ€”and was acquitted. The evidence hadn't changed. The lawyer made the difference.

climax.text: The ruling created the public defender system, transforming criminal justice for millions of Americans.

punchline.text: One handwritten letter gave millions the right to counsel.

quiz.question: What right did Gideon v. Wainwright establish?
options: Right to a lawyer if you can't afford one
